title: If riot wants to stop allegations of game states they need to start providing actual info.
body:
League of Legends is one of the only games I can think of (especially a moba) where official data isn't available.

In games like Dota, Hots, etc I can readily view my MMR, champion statistics, statistics of other players and basically anything you can think of. Hell games like overwatch you can readily see *how many bullets youve fired this season*

League of Legends your best information is literally a website that just gives a guess. And that guess is never really accurate (op.gg)

They complain about people saying things that aren't true, or using anecdotes, or saying they have no base, except they never provide any real information or source to something we can actually get credible assumptions or bases off of. This is just about as sus as you can get.

When someone says "That's not true", you need to provide data to say otherwise. And when you don't, and continue to say that, it's very clear you are hiding something.

This isn't about matchmaking, or balance, or ELO brackets, but it concerns everything. Everyone is consistently getting denied on the basis that they are 'wrong' then fail to provide literally any information stating otherwise (when usually the best guess information we have available supports them anyway)

There needs to be TRANSPARANCY.

You track all your own data for your own reasons, you have no reason not to share these types of statistics with your players unless you are very clearly hiding something.

All the sites showing builpaths, % rates, etc. all wildly vary but Riot insists that when something is brought to light, their 'data' suggests otherwise despite not sharing it.

Show it.

EDIT: Just to point out, I made this exact same thread on reddit word for word and it got shut down with negative upvotes and a deletion. Propaganda machine ahoy!

UPDATE: Reddit thread! https://www.reddit.com/r/leagueoflegends/comments/8czkqe/to_prevent_allegations_of_game_states_the/

I agree completely with this. I find it absolutely mind-boggling that one of the most popular multiplayer games in the world is still making no real effort to supply data in a manner that is clear to all, and that still relies primarily on third-party sites to supply vital information. As an editor on the LoL wiki, I've seen typos shape the entire perception of a great deal many players, including pros, which to me shows that that site, rather than any official Riot resource, is where people get information from the game, and any discussion on statistics here refers to sites like op.gg, again a third-party site. Riot's practice of denying player claims without actually substantiating their own rebuttals with data, data _they readily have at their disposal_, comes off as super shady to me, and on the few occasions where Riot has indeed produced that data, the logic and conclusions behind those posts were... questionable. I'd like to pin this on Riot still growing and learning through trial and error how to process and display data, but that's not really possible when Riot is as big as it is, or has grown for as long as it has. As such, it does feel like we the players are being deceived, or otherwise manipulated through very selective usage of data, itself pre-packaged and dressed up to suit a very specific PR goal, rather than to genuinely inform the playerbase. There is no transparency to League's data, and it feels like this issue is deliberate.

Additionally, what irritates me with Riot's recent communications strategy is that, for the most part, it's not really communicating at all. We've thankfully seen a few exceptions like Jinxylord, who takes in and directly implements player feedback, but most communication between Riot and the players is only one-way, with Riot talking _at_ us, rather than _with_ us. Back when Riot was a smaller company with a smaller playerbase, they had this phenomenal communication with their fans: while it's understandable that this communication is more difficult at a time when there are literally thousands of times more players, the problems with Riot's communication go further than that, and I think their communication has degraded overall. Besides developers who spend much less time with us players, we've gotten replies that frequently don't say anything at all. Riot themselves have repeatedly said that they don't want to announce their plans for fear that a change might disappoint us, and what few indications they give are frequently non-committal. There's no real indication of how Riot incorporates feedback or listens to players, despite their claims, and it feels more like Riot is resting on their laurels from their early days to keep telling us they have the best player communication around, even when that is clearly no longer the case. There's also been this disturbing recent trend of Rioters talking down to players, and arguing in toxic threads without contributing anything at all, while much more constructive threads remain completely unanswered. It doesn't feel like the relationship between Rioters and players really has the respect and mutual goodwill that it once had, and I don't think the critics are the only ones to blame here.

This is really well said. It's rather frustrating this entire situation. I first started using the boards because their communication with players was so good. There used to be a reason to read through the red posts because they would hint at stuff coming up or common concerns with the game. That just doesn't seem to happen anymore. The last time I remember being able to do that was leading up to Warwick's reveal. I was able to piece together most of his kit based off of red posts. After he came it started to become harder and harder to find out Riot's future plans, then Ghostcrawler's monthly Q&A disappeared, and I just stopped being able to find much of anything by the time Xayah and Rakan came out. I still have several things listed out that were supposedly planned for this year (some should have happened already), but I can't get a comment on what happened to those plans. The only solid things I know for things coming up is marksmen/bot lane work for mid-season, which is really vague and that Nunu might be getting a rework. In the past we were told exactly what preseason (think jungle rework) would be months in advanced, or that midseason would be the tank update and who those would be months in advanced with talks starting a half season prior. We have about a month now before mid-season and we don't even know really what it will be. I like something to look forward to, it helps to get me excited to continue playing. 

As an analogy for how it feels now, with everything seemingly in the dark: It feels like someone is sneaking onto my computer and adding a bunch of mods to my favorite game. I may end up liking the mods down the road, but it feels like some bit of trust has been broken between me and the mod installer. As the owner of the game in this analogy I should have a say in what I do or don't want installed. It could be that the guy installing the mods is following me around and listening to me talk about the game to friends, but if they never talk to me about it or make me a integrated part of the process, it will always feel like a parent laying down the law. 

I want the surrender@20 red posts articles to be full of rioters answering questions again instead of context quotes, I want it to take more than a few minutes to read again. I agree with this 100%. I understand Riot may want to keep totally new content somewhat of a secret, since it makes sense to build hype to an entirely new addition, but I think it is the absolute worst strategy to apply the same thing to changes to existing content. Even when a champion gets relaunched, that champion is a piece of content many players have become attached to and want to follow through development, to make sure that they turn out right. Similarly, while it's understandable that the devs may not have all the details on upcoming gameplay updates, or may change direction farther down the line, I don't think it's been healthy of Riot to keep us all in the dark when making sweeping changes to the game itself, e.g. the map, itemization, and so on. Fixing broken content is not the same as releasing new content, and Riot trying to apply the same secrecy + hype formula to both I think has had majorly negative consequences on both the game and player trust.

Also there are some studies (very few actual studies done but almost all of them) show that by not showing what rank you are or really these studies were more general but basically shows that by not showing how good someone is at something they are more likely to try harder and play longer to make sure that they are where they want to be. People if they knew they would set a goal and say something like 1900 mmr is my goal then would try super hard and once they get there they would feel accomplished and stop playing as consistently. Not saying this is everyone I'm just a normal college student that is going into video game design while taking business classes.

I don't have so much a problem with them sharing statistics, although a website that just auto updates every day on winrates and playrates that they provide would be nice, I have a problem with that they seemingly have suddenly changed how they communicate with the community. They used to talk about stuff they were planning way in advanced like the Yasuo update which we were told in a big post would happen down the line, but is seemingly cancelled (according to Repetoir). Now they don't mention anything it seems. Would you honestly be able to tell me what is planned for midseason? I couldn't. I think back on previous midseasons and I remember hearing things almost as soon as preseason ended and then them building on it as the date came closer. All we know at this point, with maybe a month left, is that it has to do with bot-lane.

When I first started playing league around season 5 end I would come on the boards and it would take me close to an hour to read the red posts on gameplay from the day prior. It took me 7 minutes to read the last weeks worth today. This is a problem for the community and Riot. How can you expect people to trust your gameplay changes if you aren't talking to them? How can players get hyped for the future of league if they don't know it? I honestly don't know what is slated beyond the Ahri changes, the Aatrox changes, the LeBlanc changes, and the Akali rework; and none of those champions particularly interest me. I have a list of changes they were looking at doing for this year before preseason shipped, but I can't expect that to be relevant info anymore because it hasn't been talked about. I thought that they were no longer doing the fighter itemization this year because it wasn't mentioned, but apparently they are. It makes me angry. I want to know what's going on in the game. I want to discuss things with Riot about which direction the game should be heading in. I don't think I should need to be asking a company to communicate with it's player basis, let alone Riot. This was supposed to be one of their strong points, something they were immensely proud of as a company when I joined, it put me at ease seeing how much they talked with us and knowing it meant they truly cared. I was prepared to take what they said at face value, as I've noted from doubting whether talked of changes are happening or not, I can't take them at face value anymore.

To any Rioter that might read this: Don't let the player-company trust die out, I know it's hard to talk on the boards right now, but ignoring it isn't going to help anything. You're losing trust simply by not communicating, and it's a lot easier to lose trust than gain it back.
